name: 17-(benzyloxy)androst-4-en-3-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1693

name: 17-(benzyloxy)androst-4-en-3-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1693
Reason: The structure of 17-(benzyloxy)androst-4-en-3-one is complex, composed of a steroid backbone fused with a benzyl ether group. The basic steroid structure, with four fused rings (three six-membered and one five-membered), would already have a relatively high melting point due to the rigid structure and van der Waals forces. An androstane structure (without any substituents) has a melting point of about 160–170°C. Adding an oxygen atom as in an ether linkage might slightly decrease the melting point due to the polar nature of the oxygen, which could disrupt crystalline packing (-5). However, the benzyl group, being a bulky and large group, can increase the melting point significantly due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions (+25). Benzyl groups tend to increase the melting point due to the aromatic ring providing extra stability and pi-pi interactions in the crystalline state (+10). Therefore, we can predict a net increase in the melting point relative to the base androstane structure.
